title: Cat. 51.4  Noa Noa (Fragrant), 1893/94, printed and published 1921
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Printed by Pola Gauguin (Danish, born France, 1883–1961), published by Christian Cato, Copenhagen  
Noa Noa (Fragrant), from the Noa Noa Suite  
1893/94, printed and published 1921  
Fourth state of four  
Wood-block print in black ink on grayish-ivory China paper; 355 × 205 mm (image); 422 × 265 mm (sheet)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, the Joseph Brooks Fair Collection, 1924.1197  
Guérin 90, Kornfeld 13 III/III, E, b, Druick/Zegers 15  
For the verso, see fig. 51.4.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">In 1921 Pola Gauguin, the artist’s son, published a posthumous edition of ten Gauguin wood-block prints, printed in an edition of one hundred, among them eight from the Noa Noa Suite. The edition was printed in black on fine, grayish-ivory China paper. With a large proportion of absorbent filler used in the formation of the sheets, the paper was particularly conducive to absorbing the black printing ink from the block. Fillers in this type of paper were commonly clay- or chalk-based and had an affinity for the wet, tacky ink. In Pola’s impressions, the ink was wiped very cleanly from the block, with the result that even the most finely incised lines that Gauguin made transferred precisely to paper. This also provides the present-day viewer with a clear understanding of the manufacture of the blocks—constructed by adhering multiple smaller segments of wood together—since many of the small gaps that had developed in them over time appear as fine, white vertical and horizontal lines scattered throughout the impressions. Similarly, the prints document the damage—small scratches and cracks—suffered by the blocks before 1921, as well as minute, delicate incising added by a later hand to clean up the blocks, perhaps in anticipation of the posthumous printing.

When placed side by side with the many unique impressions pulled by Gauguin, the impressions pulled by Pola lack tonal variation and differ greatly in appearance. Gauguin sought to obscure much of the gouged and incised detail carved into his blocks by unevenly and selectively inking them and by hand applying media to the block, the printed paper, or both. In contrast, Pola’s impressions have a crisp accuracy and legibility that allow them to be used as road maps to navigate the imagery that was very consciously obscured in Gauguin’s impressions (fig. 51.4.2 and fig. 51.4.3).

Several segments of the block used for this print (1893–94; Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York), which was constructed from nine small pieces of end-grain boxwood, cracked or shifted out of plane at some point before the 1921 printing. These uninked areas resulted in visual breaks in the printed composition that appear along the top edge at center, horizontally across the width of the impression 118 mm down from the top and 119 mm up from the bottom, and extending 73 mm in from the right and 129 mm up from the bottom.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 51.4.4).

The posthumous impressions were printed with ink that is a mixture of carbon black and Prussian blue. The cool cast of the ink is attributable to the blue pigment. The block was printed in a straightforward manner using a press. This undertaking was carried out in Copenhagen by the publisher Christian Cato, and according to Pola Gauguin the blocks were printed using “a book press and two cylinders, one of moistened rubber and one of hard leather.” It is quite apparent that this impression was printed with a hard leather roller so the ink would remain on the surface of the block rather than slip into the interstices. The consistency of the ink must have been quite tacky to sit on the surface of the block in this way. Because only the hightest points were inked, the rings of the wood absorbed the ink selectively and as such are visible in a section of the print to the right of the figure on the right.

The paper fibers in the thin, grayish-ivory China paper are more or less uniform, with minute fibrous inclusions throughout. Calcium carbonate (chalk) was used as a filler to give the sheet its opaque, matte appearance and soft, velvety feel. There is a series of brush marks incised into the paper. A hallmark of China paper, these brush marks form when a hard-bristled brush is used to brush out the paper onto a hard surface to dry. Dragging the brush through the chalk-laden paper results in the pattern of brushwork seen here (fig. 51.4.5). In transmitted light, a mold impression characteristic of China paper is visible; chain lines appear at various intervals across the sheet and laid lines are very fine and spaced close together. The distribution of the varied paper fibers is also visible. Under magnification the paper fibers appear long and evenly distributed throughout the sheet. Some darker fibers of various lengths can be seen throughout. The ink is evenly dispersed on the surface. Creases that formed during the printing process are readily visible, and the lack of ink in overlapping areas of creasing is apparent. Embossment of the paper is pronounced in raking light. Pola’s impressions were not printed with the same degree of variable pressure as that applied by Gauguin. As a result, they are not as deeply embossed as the lifetime impressions examined for this study. However, the paper in the image area exhibits pressure-induced undulations associated with the use of a press and the significant pressure exerted in printing the block.

In 1938 Pola outlined his trials and tribulations as he worked out his method to print his father’s blocks. He stated that he purchased the blocks in 1919, and it must have been under the guidance of the Cato firm that he came to familiarize himself with the China paper favored by printers the world over by the late nineteenth century. Given the nuance and skill required to print such fine impressions, it is inconceivable to the authors that Pola printed the blocks alone, without relying upon the expertise he found in Cato’s firm.

355 × 205 mm (image); 422 × 265 mm (sheet). The image was centered on the sheet with substantial borders of approximately 30 mm on each side. The sheet has deckled edges along the right, top, and bottom edges. The left edge was cut with scissors. Along the bottom edge there is residue of red ink of the type customarily used to add export stamps to the outside of large bundled stacks of paper. It is likely that large sheets of China paper were cut into halves or quarters to provide sheets of dimensions appropriate for printing Gauguin’s elongated blocks. For this impression, the printer appears to have cut a large sheet of paper in half.

The publisher gave careful consideration to the manner of presentation of this group of wood-block prints. The images were centered on the large sheets of China paper with ample borders on all sides. The sheets of China paper were in turn pasted onto sturdy sheets of mottled blue wove paper in each of the four corners (fig. 51.4.6). Blue fibrous inclusions appear throughout (fig. 51.4.7). Ample borders were again provided. The choice of this paper for mounting was not a random one, but one quite common in the latter part of the nineteenth century. It also reflected Gauguin’s own preference for mounting a number of his prints, including some from his Noa Noa Suite and Oviri (see cat. 84.3 and cat. 84.4). Once mounted, the ten prints and a letterpress title page were placed in a portfolio constructed of gray millboard adorned with the cartouche from another plate in the suite, Te po (The Night) (cat. 52), on the cover (fig. 51.4.8).

Posthumous impressions in the Art Institute of Chicago are no longer mounted, the title page (fig. 51.4.9) was trimmed, and only the top of the portfolio cover (fig. 51.4.10) is extant; it too was trimmed.

The print is in excellent condition overall. In anticipation of this publication, the work was conserved to remove residual hinges and adhesive that had caused the sheet to undulate in the areas where they were adhered. Areas of undulation were locally humidified and flattened. Examination under ultraviolet light reveals extensive foxing throughout on both the recto and verso that is not visible in normal light (see fig. 51.4.1). These areas fluoresce more brightly than the paper.  
Harriet K. Stratis with the assistance of Mary Broadway

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Sold by Thomas W. Schreiner, New York, to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1924.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">Auckland (New Zealand) City Art Gallery, Paul Gauguin: Pages from the Pacific, Aug. 4–Oct. 15, 1995, cat. 15 (ill.).

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Douglas Druick and Peter Zegers, Paul Gauguin: Pages from the Pacific, exh. cat. (Auckland City Art Gallery/Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), pp. 40, 51, cat. 15 (ill.).

Britt Salvesen, Gauguin, in association with Douglas W. Druick and Peter Kort Zegers, Artists in Focus (Art Institute of Chicago/Abrams, 2001), pp. 90, 109, no. 18a (ill.).

Peter Kort Zegers, “In the Kitchen with Paul Gauguin: Devising Recipes for a Symbolist Graphic Aesthetic,” in The Broad Spectrum: Studies in the Materials, Techniques, and Conservation of Color on Paper, ed. Harriet K. Stratis and Britt Salvesen (Archetype Publications, 2002), pp. 138–40, fig. 3.1.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Signed lower right, below image, in pale silvery-purple graphite (copy pencil?): Pola Gauguin imp

Inscribed lower left, below image, in pale silvery-purple graphite (copy pencil?): Paul Gauguin fait

Inscribed upper left, above image, in pale silvery-purple graphite (copy pencil?): no. 50

Collection stamp in oval, lower left, in brown ink: THE ART / INSTITUTE OF / CHICAGO

Inscribed lower left, below image, in graphite: A. I. C. / 24.1203

Inscribed lower left, below image, in graphite, partially erased: acc. no. 6395

Inscribed lower left, in graphite: 6395

The media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (8–10×), and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Gauguin returned to Tahiti with the blocks for Te atua (The God) and Te faruru (Here We Make Love); hence, they were not included in Pola’s edition.

According to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the block consists of nine sections of fruitwood (probably pear) joined together and sprung along horizontal joinings. The means of identification of the wood is not indicated.

Using the toolbar at the bottom right, any two images of the artwork may be selected for comparison by clicking the layers icon to the right of the slider bar. The slider bar may be moved to transition back and forth between the two chosen images. Where annotations are available, the jagged-line icon brings up a list of them, or colored lines that show the significant features visible in each image, which may be turned on or off in any combination. For example, the red annotation lines, associated with the natural-light image, trace some of the artwork’s key compositional features. When overlaid onto a technical image (X-ray, raking light, ultraviolet, etc.), the red outlines help the viewer to better observe how features in the technical image relate to or diverge from the artwork as seen with the naked eye. (When annotations are turned on, a legend appears in the upper right showing each color and its associated image type.) The circular-arrow icon returns the image to the default settings (natural light, full-image view, natural-light [red] annotation on). The four-arrow icon toggles between the view of the image in the page and a full-screen view of the image. In the upper right corner, the vertical slider bar may be moved to zoom into or out of the image; different parts of the image can be accessed by clicking and dragging within the image itself. The icon in the upper left corner opens a small view of the full image, within which a red box indicates the portion of the overall image being viewed when zooming is enabled.

Pigment analysis of the ink was carried out using FTIR on Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (cat. 55.5) and Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) (cat. 60.4). Carbon black was identified as likely, and is mixed with Prussian blue. See Céline Daher, Dec. 2015, XRF analytical results summary, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago. Although these were the only posthumous prints analyzed, visual examination of multiple examples of posthumous impressions revealed that these works were all printed with the same type of ink. The tonality of the ink and its appearance on the paper are the same in all of them.

Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine E. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), pp. 48–49.

XRF analysis identified calcium carbonate (chalk) as the filler in Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (cat. 55.5) and Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) (cat. 60.4). See Céline Daher, XRF analytical results summary, Dec. 2015, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago. Although these were the only posthumous print analyzed, visual examination of multiple examples of posthumous impressions revealed that these works were all printed on the same type of paper. The surface quality and tonality of the paper are the same in all of them.

I am grateful to Mel Becker Solomon for bringing Pola Gauguin’s 1938 essay in Galerie und Sammler (no. 6) to my attention. In the essay Pola expands upon what he had written in his 1935 letter to Jean-Gabriel Daragnès, published in Arts et métiers graphiques 49 (Oct. 15, 1935), p. 40.

Correspondence dated April 2014 between Christine Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld) and Sten Rasmussen (buyer of NB Offset A/S and by descent the Cato Lithographic Establishment) states that he acquired a set of Pola impressions from the Cato archives along with the business. A document among Carl Schneiwind’s papers held in the Art Institute of Chicago, Department of Prints and Drawings, states that Pola lived next door to Cato and that “Cato probably made [the] Pola ed.”

Edgar Degas owned prints from the Noa Noa Suite that were mounted on mottled blue paper. See Ann Dumas, “Degas and His Collection,” in Dumas, Colta Ives, Susan Alyson Stein, and Gary Tinterow, The Private Collection of Edgar Degas: A Summary Catalogue (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, 1997), p. 57. An impression of Nave nave fenua mounted on mottled blue paper is in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York; the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, owns mounted impressions of Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) and Te po (The Night).

In the Art Institute of Chicago collection there is a portfolio of fifteen lithographs after Degas by Georges William Thornley (1857–1935) published by Boussod, Valadon et Cie. that are mounted in a similar fashion. The portfolio cover is intact. See also the Commentary for cat. 51.

An intact example of the portfolio in the collection of the British Museum, London, was examined for this study. The observations made here are based on that examination.

I am grateful to Peter Zegers for so generously sharing his insights into Pola Gauguin’s posthumous edition of the Noa Noa Suite.

Harriet Stratis, condition report, 1995, conservation object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

fig. 51.4.8 The gray millboard portfolio cover containing Gauguin’s Noa Noa Suite, printed and published in 1921 by the artist’s son Pola Gauguin. The cartouche in the center is from another plate in the suite, Te po (The Night). The British Museum, London. Photograph by Harriet K. Stratis.
